executive_summary: The Hops Farming industry produces hops primarily for sale to brewers and third-party dealers and distributors. Hops are a primary ingredient in the production of beer. Industry performance over the five years to 2020 can be characterized by strong demand and prices early during the period, followed by a leveling off in 2018 and disruption in 2020 due to the outbreak of COVID-19. Industry revenue is expected to rise an annualized 11.3% to reach $639.6 million. However, this includes an anticipated decline of 0.6% in 2020 alone as end markets are roiled by the coronavirus pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Craft Beer Boom Continues to Drive Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Compared with other beers, [a certain type of beer] has skyrocketed in popularity during the period, leading craft breweries to place larger orders of hops from industry operators. Overall, market trends have been favorable to the industry, as IPAs account for 26.0% of revenue in the Craft Beer Production industry in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic Offers Minimal Disruption for Hops Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020 when the COVID-19 pandemic began, alcohol sales fell briefly due to bars and restaurants being forced to close. This in turn led to lower demand for hops, the key ingredient in beer. However, hops growers limited production in 2020 to adjust for the disruption, leading to higher hops prices and a less severe revenue decline.

As a climate-sensitive crop, hops are vulnerable to the ongoing effects of climate change. Crops need rainy springs and hot summers, so droughts in the Northwest could threaten the country's hops supply. Hops farms in Oregon have been especially threatened by wildfires.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Small Farms Are Here to Stay
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the Hops Farming industry has generations-old family farms, the craft beer boom created the opportunity for investors to purchase small farms and begin cultivating hops. Hops farming is capital-intense, but resource sharing agreements and co-operative farm groups have been able to reduce overall costs making the industry friendly to new farms.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The economy has fully moved beyond the COVID-19 pandemic, and supply chains are likely to fully stabilize in the coming years. For this reason, hops farms are not likely to struggle to source equipment, seeds, fertilizer or other inputs. Without these disruptions, hops farms will see more stability and be able to generate more robust profit and revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Changing Climate Could Threaten Future Harvests
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wildfires, droughts and other natural disasters that come as a result of climate change can quickly destroy or alter hops plants in the Northwest. Most significantly, wildfires can destroy farmland and taint hops with smoke. Climate change has led to increased wildfires, and this trend is likely to continue, creating new uncertainty for hops farms.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Craft Beer Market Provides Stable Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Following the boom of the 2010's, craft beer has become a staple of US drinking culture. While alcohol consumption rates may change over the next five years, craft beer is here to stay. Despite volatility brought on by other external factors, demand for hops is likely to remain high and provide hops farmers with a consistent market for their crops.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Overseas Competition Limits Potential for Export Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While US hops have dominated in overseas markets, other countries have been improving their hops cultivation. Exports will remain high, because US hops can only be grown in the specific climate of the US. However, other countries are beginning to develop their own unique hop varieties for craft beer markets. New foreign hops varieties will yield greater competition in overseas markets and growth in the value of imports.

industry_definition: The Hops Farming industry grows hops primarily for sale to brewers and third-party dealers and distributors.
key_trends: The craft beer boom has driven strong demand for hops from breweries
Climate change is impacting hops harvests through droughts, wildfires, etc.
Small hops farms have been able to enter the market due to the craft beer trend
The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted the industry temporarily in 2020
Overseas competition is increasing for export markets as other countries improve hops cultivation

market_segmentation.segment_description: As more small farms have entered the industry, a greater portion of hops sales have gone through distributors. Small hops farms are rarely able to sell their crops directly to brewers, so distributors bridge this gap.

The craft beer boom has not just been limited to the US. Even countries with traditional national beer styles like Belgium, Germany and Ireland have begun embracing American beers like wild American ales and New England IPAs.

Most direct sales between hops farms and brewers involve massive breweries with consistent supply contracts. That's why as large breweries lose market share, direct sales are dropping off for hops farms.

products_and_services.product_description: Dual hops provide aromas and bitterness.
Aromatic hops have a broader range of flavors, making them apt for innovation.
The data shows that bittering hops make up 28.7% of the hops industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: BITTER BEERS FALL OUT OF FAVOR WITH DRINKERS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: While bitter IPAs were once a staple of craft beer culture, consumers have recently been moving toward more flavorful and fruit-forward beers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: FARMS USE AROMATIC HOPS TO EXPERIMENT AND INNOVATE
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Hops farmers are known to experiment and try to develop new varieties of hops. While there are different varieties of bittering hops, aromatic hops have a broader range of flavors, making them apt for innovation.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: DUAL HOPS DOMINATE THROUGH BROAD APPEAL
demand_determinants.determinant_description: More than half of US-grown hops are dual hops that provide aromas and bitterness. Most varieties of hops are dual.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Foreign Hops Provide Different Beer Style Options
international_trade_points.trade_description: Countries known for distinct beer styles have been able to claim a portion of the domestic hops market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports are needed to keep up with booming demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: Since hops are easily affected by the climate they're grown in, imported hops have flavors and aromas that US hops can't develop under normal growing conditions.
As the US has led the way in the craft beer market, brewers in other countries have sought US hops so they can produce popular American-style beers like IPAs and sours.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Export growth will slow as foreign competition rises
international_trade_points.trade_description: Demand for US hops has been high among countries with historic beer production, because these countries don't cultivate a variety of hops styles.

regulations_points.regulation_title: US DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FEDERAL GRAIN INSPECTION SERVICE
regulations_points.regulation_description: The USDA requires that all hops grown for commercial use receive a Federal-State Seed, Leaf and Stem inspection certificate before they can be sold. In 2019 the USDA updated its hop inspection manual that sets the standards [Requirements] that hops farms must meet.

The 2018 Farm Bill is the latest version of the bill that provides funding for programs throughout the Agriculture sector. The farm bill includes funding for disease control initiatives that affect hops farmers.

basis_points.basis_title: Hard seltzer threatens the market for hops
basis_points.basis_description: While hops have few direct substitutes, if breweries face increased competition, this also threatens hops farms.

basis_points.basis_title: Foreign hops growers offer unique styles
basis_points.basis_description: While US hops dominate the global market, other countries have increased hops production with varieties that the US can't grow.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large Brewers Control the Largest Hops Growers
concentration_points.concentration_description: The largest hops farm in the US, Elk Mountain Farms, is owned by Anheuser-Busch Companies, LLC, the country's largest brewery.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most Farms Have Few Employees and a Small Market Share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Hops farms don't need a significant number of employees, because the process of planting, harvesting and drying hops is not highly labor intense.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation costs tower in comparison to farming industries
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hops farming is highly mechanized compared to most farming industries and exhibits a high level of capital intensity. Depreciable assets include harvesting equipment and drying equipment as well as warehouses and storage space.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Growing conditions lead to high utility costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hops are a water-intensive crop that require constant drip irrigation. Hops require water but do not do well near standing water. Meanwhile, hops must be stored in temperature controlled cold-storage environments to preserve flavor and prevent spoilage.

volatility_points.volatility_title: AS CRAFT BEER BECOMES THE NORM, VOLATILITY BEGINS TO DECLINE
volatility_points.volatility_description: As demand for craft beer began to surge in the 2010's, hops production had to increase to keep up. For this reason, hops farms saw double-digit revenue growth until 2017. While the craft beer bubble was expected to burst, demand has instead remained high.

volatility_points.volatility_title: HIGHER TEMPERATURES HAVE HELPED AND HINDERED HOPS PRODUCTION
volatility_points.volatility_description: Hops plants yield their best results when rainy springs are followed by warm summers, and for the past five years, the Northwest has been able to provide these conditions. These weather patterns have helped reduce volatility in this region.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: BITTER BEERS FALL OUT OF FAVOR WITH DRINKERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While bitter IPAs were once a staple of craft beer culture, consumers have recently been moving toward more flavorful and fruit-forward beers. Bittering hops are still needed in beer production, but with greater demand for aromatic hops, some farms are shifting their production toward higher value crops.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: FARMS USE AROMATIC HOPS TO EXPERIMENT AND INNOVATE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Hops farmers are known to experiment and try to develop new varieties of hops. While there are different varieties of bittering hops, aromatic hops have a broader range of flavors, making them apt for innovation. This innovation has led to greater demand from brewers that want to find new flavors without using additives.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DUAL HOPS DOMINATE THROUGH BROAD APPEAL
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: More than half of US-grown hops are dual hops that provide aromas and bitterness. Most varieties of hops are dual. Brewers use dual hops to add a broader range of flavors to their beers. Some large brewers also use dual hops for simplicity's sake.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of hops?
FAQs.answer: Diversified producers will exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. Non-diversified producers will be more subject to output price fluctuations, hindering profitability.

FAQs.question: Do sales depend on the health of the economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for hops tends to be stable and sales beer of which are more dependent on disposable income levels.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts with downstream customers will exhibit more stable revenue. Producers that exercise input-price and supply management will have a better time planning next year's crop, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Producers located in proximity to key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Producers located in proximity to key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Does your company invest in the latest technologies to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Crop yields can be improved and stabilized via automated technology such as drones and crop monitors, making for more stable harvests. Labor costs can further be reduced through the use of seasonal labor in conjunction with the latest technologies.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs can be reduced by adopting auto-steering and GPS guided tractors. Operators leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Producers with a penchant for environmentally friendly and organic produce may be favored by the public, Noncompliant producers will be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant producers will exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Noncompliant producers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: How do your profit margins compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against profit margin volatility.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have higher levels of inventory turnover, boosting sales. Producers that do not have a relationship with downstream purchased will have a more difficult time moving inventory in a quick and efficient manner.
